list.definition: A sustained fight between large organized armed forces.
An aggressive action against a person or place to cause damage or injury.
A physical attack or threat that causes fear of harm.
A surprise attack from a concealed position.
A place where weapons and military equipment are stored.
The criminal act of deliberately setting fire to property.
An effort to cut off supplies or communication to a place.
The act of attacking with explosive devices.
A person killed or injured in a war or accident.
Soldiers who fight mounted on horseback or armored vehicles.
To suppress or control information, often during wartime.
A rapid forward attack against an enemy position.
A person not in the armed services or the police force.
A senior military officer rank below general.
A group of vehicles or ships traveling together for protection.
Violations of law; in wartime can include war crimes.
Exposure to harm, risk, or injury.
The end of life caused by violence, disease, or accident.
A loss in battle or conflict; the opposite of victory.
To make a dangerous situation safe, such as disarming explosives.
To position troops or resources for military action.
To abandon a post or duty.
An explosive used to demolish.
An official ban on trade with a particular country.
A mass departure of people, often refugees fleeing violence.
Those who have died in combat; casualties.
An authoritarian and nationalistic right-wing system of government.
A person or animal that fights.
A portable gun.
Made to do something against one's will.
The military line or part of an army that is closest to the enemy.
Troops stationed to defend an area.
The deliberate killing of a large group of people.
A small bomb thrown by hand or launched mechanically.
A soldier who operates a gun or artillery.
Unfriendly; antagonistic.
To move at high speed; used for projectiles.
To enter a country or place by force.
A rebel fighting established authority.
To push or shove roughly in chaotic settings.
Having been caused to die; result of lethal violence.
To take someone away illegally by force.
To set an attack, missile, or operation into motion.
The brutal killing of many people.
An area planted with explosive mines.
Attacked or overwhelmed by a crowd; mob violence.
A short artillery piece used to fire explosive shells.
The unlawful killing of another person with intent.
An incendiary substance used in warfare.
Strong identification with one's nation.
To take control of a place by military force.
An aggressive military operation.
A group sent out to monitor an area for security.
To rob a place using violence.
A substance that can cause harm or death.
A place where captives or detainees are held.
Action intended to elicit a hostile response.
A person or idea seeking extreme change, sometimes violent.
A slender, pointed sword used historically in combat.
To attack or invade suddenly and briefly.
Payment demanded for the release of a captive.
A person forced to flee due to war.
Deliberate destruction or obstruction.
Surrounding and isolating a place to compel surrender.
Explosive artillery ammunition used to bombard positions.
Killed violently; to slay someone is to murder them.
A marksman who shoots from concealed positions at long range.
A sudden attack, often by air or missile.
To bring under control or suppress by force.
Provision of equipment, food, or ammunition for operations.
To give up or cease resistance.
A long ditch used to protect soldiers from enemy fire.
Acts intended to create fear and coerce populations.
Inflicting severe pain to punish or extract information.
A self-propelled underwater missile used to destroy ships.
A state of disturbance often leading to protests or violence.
A revolt or rebellion.
Deliberate destruction of property.
A state or person in a subordinate position to a ruler.
A person harmed or killed as a result of violence.
Behavior involving physical force.
The act of breaking laws or rights.
A group organized for waging war.
A leader controlling territory by force.
Tools used to inflict harm.
Persons injured in combat or violent incidents.
Extreme anger or violent retribution.
A heavily armed military aircraft used for close air support.
An attack by military aircraft.
A group of civilian fighters organized for military service.
A strong defensive fortification, often underground.
A small military station distant from the main force.
A withdrawal of troops to avoid defeat or regroup.
Forces conducting sudden attacks to harass or loot.
An individual who serves in an army and engages in combat.
Buildings used to house soldiers or military personnel.
To attack persistently with artillery or bombs.
An armed force or person that enters by force to occupy.
To take control of a person, place, or thing by force.
A person held to secure the fulfillment of terms.
To break free from confinement or dangerous situation.
An entity that obstructs movement or supply lines.
Small metal projectiles fired from firearms.
A blade attached to the muzzle of a rifle for close combat.
Aiming reticle used in firearms optics.
Scattered fragments from destruction or explosion.
Deliberate destruction of structures.
A person who joins the armed forces.
Trade or swap; in war, sometimes of prisoners or territory.
A planned withdrawal to a more defensible position.
An intense fire spread over an area.
Attacked from the side or exposed to side attack.
Involving the use of physical power.
A soldier specialized with grenades or assault roles.
A sheltered area for ships; strategic naval target.
Unfriendly or antagonistic, often in military context.
Forceful strikes or collisions causing damage.
Foot soldiers engaged in ground combat.
To frighten or coerce by threats or force.
Refers to fighters practicing jihad; can be violent militants.
Mythical sea monster; used metaphorically for destructive forces.
To prevent access; in war can mean sealing an area.
A raider who plunders.
Groups displaced by conflict moving without a fixed home.
Held and controlled by a foreign force.
Displaced people traveling.
Providing mercy or shelter; sometimes denied in warfare.
Predatory aircraft or metaphor for aggressive force.
A bag filled with sand used for protection against blasts.
Methods used to conduct a siege.
Armored combat vehicles used on the battlefield.
To displace or remove people from their homes.
Cruelly violent or aggressive behavior.
Engagements between armed forces using organized violence.
Fear of foreigners that can lead to violence.
To give way under pressure; surrender in conflict contexts.
An extremist committed to an ideology, sometimes violently.
Delivery of supplies or equipment by aircraft into a combat zone.
An attack or plan that has the opposite effect intended.
A concentrated artillery bombardment over a wide area.
Violent beating or assault by a group or individual.
Acting in a frenzied or uncontrolled violent manner.
Destruction by fire or exhaustion of resources in conflict.
A military aircraft designed to drop bombs.
A major tactical military formation that is typically composed of three to six battalions.
A projectile for firing from a rifle, revolver, or other small firearm.
A large, heavy piece of artillery, typically mounted on wheels.
Fighting between armed forces.
A soldier specially trained to carry out raids.
A serious disagreement or clash, often armed.
A vigorous campaign for some cause, historically violent.
The action of defending from or resisting attack.
To destroy or ruin a building or structure, often in war.
The act of holding someone in custody.
A person who is actively opposed or hostile to someone or something.
A violent and destructive shattering or blowing apart of something.
An intense fire spread over an area.
The side of a person's or animal's body between the ribs and the hip.
A military stronghold.
The deliberate killing of a large group of people.
A person who keeps watch, especially a soldier or other person assigned to protect a person or to control access to a place.
The shooting of guns.
A man who uses a gun to commit a crime or terrorist act.
A shot fired from a gun.
A hard or padded protective hat.
Harm or damage.
An active revolt or uprising.
A fast military aircraft designed for air-to-air combat.
The act of causing death, especially deliberately.
An explosive mine laid on or just under the surface of the ground.
The person who leads or commands a group, organization, or country.
An automatic gun that fires bullets in rapid succession.
A metal disc typically of the kind awarded for bravery or service in war.
The armed forces of a country.
A weapon that is self-propelled or directed by remote control.
An important assignment carried out for political, religious, or commercial purposes.
The branch of a nation's armed services that conducts military operations at sea.
An attacking military campaign.
Someone who competes against or fights another in a contest, game, or argument.
A public procession, especially one celebrating a special day or event including military.
A member of a group of soldiers trained to parachute from aircraft.
A person who maintains or restores peace and order.
A person who operates the flying controls of an aircraft.
A subdivision of a company of soldiers.
A person legally held in prison as a punishment for crimes committed or while awaiting trial.
A statement or action expressing disapproval of or objection to something.
A system for detecting the presence, direction, distance, and speed of objects.
A period of violent and uncontrollable behavior.
An act of violent or open resistance to an established government or ruler.
A permanent unit of an army.
To save someone from a dangerous or distressing situation.
Rise in rebellion.
A forcible overthrow of a government or social order.
A gun, especially one fired from shoulder level.
A missile, spacecraft, aircraft or other vehicle that obtains thrust from a rocket engine.
An act of giving up something valued for the sake of something else.
A non-commissioned officer in the armed forces.
A person who uses a gun.
Fragments of a bomb, shell, or other object thrown out by an explosion.
A device for reducing the noise emitted by a gun.
The killing of animals for food; or killing of people in a cruel or violent way.
A small group of people having a particular task.
A plan of action designed to achieve a long-term or overall aim.
A warship with a streamlined hull designed to operate underwater.
A person who survives, especially a person remaining alive after an event in which others have died.
An action or strategy carefully planned to achieve a specific end.
A heavy armored fighting vehicle carrying guns and moving on a continuous articulated metal track.
The unlawful use of violence and intimidation, especially against civilians.
A person who uses unlawful violence and intimidation.
A person who betrays someone or something.
A device or enclosure designed to catch and retain animals or people.
Soldiers or armed forces.
A cup or other decorative object awarded as a prize for a victory or success.
A small tower on top of a larger tower or at the corner of a building or wall.
The distinctive clothing worn by members of the same organization or body.
A thing used for transporting people or goods.
An act of defeating an enemy or opponent in a battle, game, or other competition.
Engagement in or the activities involved in war or conflict.
The explosive head of a missile, torpedo, or similar weapon.
A military commander, especially an aggressive regional commander with individual autonomy.
A brave or experienced soldier or fighter.
A thing designed or used for inflicting bodily harm or physical damage.
Injured, especially with a cut or other injury to the body.
A large German dirigible airship of the early 20th century.
A policy of extending a country's power and influence through diplomacy or military force.
The process by which a society organizes itself for military conflict and violence.
Involving or causing a complete or dramatic change, often through force.
Military or political action taken against the activities of guerrillas or revolutionaries.
A person who promotes or publicizes a particular cause or ideology, often in war.
The policy of intervening in the affairs of another country.
Military observation of a region to locate an enemy or ascertain strategic features.
False information spread deliberately to deceive, often used in geopolitical conflicts.
The act of setting up a colony away from one's place of origin, often by force.
Standing down a nation's armed forces from combat-ready status.
The act of bringing someone or something under domination or control.
Complete destruction or obliteration, often used in the context of war.
A military force that occupies and controls a territory.
Relating to politics, especially international relations, as influenced by geographical factors.
The process of depriving a person or group of positive human qualities, often used in war propaganda.
Compensation imposed during peace treaties for the damage caused during war.
The state of being confined in prison; imprisonment, often used as a tool of political repression.
The act of a government taking privately owned property to be used for the benefit of the public.
A form of irregular warfare in which small groups use military tactics to fight a larger traditional military.
The use of propaganda, threats, and other psychological techniques to mislead, intimidate, or demoralize an opponent.
Radio communication meaning 'message received and understood.'
The disputed ground between the front lines of two opposing armies.
Weapon fire coming from one's own side, accidentally harming allies.
A state of emergency or heightened alert.
Gunfire provided to protect troops while they move.
A serious violation of the laws of war.
Negotiations to end conflict or war.
The point of detonation of a bomb, especially a nuclear one.
A warning of imminent danger or attack.
A covert operation designed to deceive by appearing as if carried out by another group.
A command center for military planning and operations.
A diamond mined in a war zone and sold to finance conflict.
Secret or covert military operations.
A state of political hostility without direct military conflict.
A war between groups within the same country.
Military government involving the suspension of ordinary law.
A shouted word or phrase used to rally troops before battle.
The ground on which a battle is fought.
A sequence of events, often used to describe nuclear explosions.
Protective measures taken by civilians in case of attack.
A person used to deter attacks by placing them in harm's way.
A country's military forces and infrastructure.
A large broad-bladed weapon used in combat.
A prolonged conflict between families or groups involving revenge killings.
A strategy or plan for conducting a battle.
Funds set aside for conducting a war or campaign.
A person admired for bravery in war.
A woman who marries a soldier during wartime.
A drum used to signal or motivate troops in battle.
